text.text: A Guide to Nunhead & Brockley

text.html: Souf, souf, souf of the river: rubbing shoulders with the popular, buzzing ends of Peckham and Deptford respectively, Nunhead and Brockley aren’t as far away as they might sound to the untrained ear. In fact, they’re laaaavly lil’ communities and there’s a bunch of stuff worth checking out. We’ll do the nice thing and hold your hand: come on now, pet, let’s have it large!
text.text: Souf, souf, souf of the river: rubbing shoulders with the popular, buzzing ends of Peckham and Deptford respectively, Nunhead and Brockley aren’t as far away as they might sound to the untrained ear. In fact, they’re laaaavly lil’ communities and there’s a bunch of stuff worth checking out. We’ll do the nice thing and hold your hand: come on now, pet, let’s have it large!
Nunhead
Best for… breakfast, brunch and all that biznezz

tip.text:
***Permanently Closed***


Nunhead natives are well excited about this new spot; just you try and wriggle your way through the door at brunch ‘o'clock on a Saturday. The good folk at The Habit will say the more the merrier - they set out to feed the honest people of SE 15 and that’s exactly what they’re doing. Fresh, local produce and boy do these guys know what’s up - John, one of the owners, has a fine dining cheffing past and you know what they say about old habits...

text.text: Nunhead natives are well excited about this new spot; just you try and wriggle your way through the door at brunch ‘o'clock on a Saturday. The good folk at The Habit will say the more the merrier - they set out to feed the honest people of SE 15 and that’s exactly what they’re doing. Fresh, local produce and boy do these guys know what’s up - John, one of the owners, has a fine dining cheffing past and you know what they say about old habits...
Best for… putting quality solids and liquids inside your person

tip.text:
Open until midnight on school nights and 1am at the weekends, The Old Nun's Head is a wicked late night spot for those in need of letting their hair down after a long-ass day in the office. With four guest ales on tap, an extensive wine list and plenty of other bottled goodies all at cheerful prices, you'll probably have a tough time trying to leave this place.

Hungry? These guys have different kitchen residencies on different weekdays, from 'I Should Be Souvlaki' Greek wraps, to Burger Bear and Le Bao (steamed buns). Yeah, it's a lot to take in, so work up an appetite.
Catch DJs spinning into the night on weekends, while a beer garden with much foliage makes Nunhead look more like Namibia (if you've got your beer goggles on).

Check out their quiz on a Thursday at 8pm.

text.html: Things you want from a pub: good beer; decent nibbles; a garden with benches and a bit of foliage; the odd weekend knees-up. It’s not much to ask but the Old Nun’s head are so on point they’re ticking outside of the box: there’s actually just so much to get down your trap in here. All sorts of crafty, cask ales and different, delicious food residencies four days a week; plus funk, soul & disco DJs every weekend. ARE YOU NOT ENTERTAINED?
text.text: Things you want from a pub: good beer; decent nibbles; a garden with benches and a bit of foliage; the odd weekend knees-up. It’s not much to ask but the Old Nun’s head are so on point they’re ticking outside of the box: there’s actually just so much to get down your trap in here. All sorts of crafty, cask ales and different, delicious food residencies four days a week; plus funk, soul & disco DJs every weekend. ARE YOU NOT ENTERTAINED?
Best for… casting your sights over the united kingdom that is LDN

tip.text:
Sometimes in London you're just taken aback: turn a corner, or walk up a hill, and suddenly find yourself struck with a stunning, cinematic view of the city. Nunhead's Telegraph Hill provides one of these such moments, its tennis courts and grassy banks seemingly on top of the world from this vantage point.

Walk your dog; swing a racket; stick a blanket down and get involved in a picnic - you can't go wrong with a spot like this on a sunny day.

text.html: If you can’t appreciate the beauty of a skyline view from a grassy, city vantage point then you’re a complete mug and we give up. Telegraph Hill Park is absolutely killing it, yet rarely is it mentioned as one of London’s go-to spots for kicking back and soaking in the spectacular sight that is The Big Smoke from afar. You might not be Andy Murray, but have a cheeky game of tennis up here and legit feel on top of the world.
text.text: If you can’t appreciate the beauty of a skyline view from a grassy, city vantage point then you’re a complete mug and we give up. Telegraph Hill Park is absolutely killing it, yet rarely is it mentioned as one of London’s go-to spots for kicking back and soaking in the spectacular sight that is The Big Smoke from afar. You might not be Andy Murray, but have a cheeky game of tennis up here and legit feel on top of the world.
Best for… a surprise in the garden

tip.text:
Skehans is a proper family boozer, small in size but large in stature. Here regular live music, pool, darts, footie, old blokes necking Guinness and arty moochers from Goldsmith’s fill the space and create one of the best pub atmospheres in town. It's a unique mishmash melting pot and the result is goddamn good craic.

Set up in an old Victorian corner pub, it’s got the look and feel you want from your local; where, as things get wild after dark, you get the sense the night could go anywhere. Meanwhile, out back is a rare unexpected gem: a leafy garden with a converted coach house doing very tasty Thai food to complete this perfect pub package.

text.html: You know them ones when your local old man’s boozer has a full-blown Thai restaurant under a canopy of foliage out back? No? They don’t have that everywhere? Pubs of London, sit down and take note: this is how you spring a damn surprise! Outdoor seating, front and back, makes Skehans a tidy spot for a pint in the sun, but it’s Mr. Chai’s in the garden that really makes this is a singular joint.
text.text: You know them ones when your local old man’s boozer has a full-blown Thai restaurant under a canopy of foliage out back? No? They don’t have that everywhere? Pubs of London, sit down and take note: this is how you spring a damn surprise! Outdoor seating, front and back, makes Skehans a tidy spot for a pint in the sun, but it’s Mr. Chai’s in the garden that really makes this is a singular joint.
Best for… a spot of quiet reflection

tip.text: Part of London's 'Magnificent Seven' Victorian cemeteries, this peaceful and leafy burial site makes for a touching and calming visit. Whether paying respects, admiring derelict and abandoned churches, or just enjoying a tranquil walk with man's best friend (your dog), Nunhead Cemetery is a real treat of an open space. A perfect place for collecting one's thoughts, this feels like a real escape from the big city.

text.html: Perhaps the least well known of London’s ‘Magnificent Seven’ Victorian cemeteries (alongside the likes of Highgate and Kensal Green), this grassy and tranquil burial site makes for an idyllic escape from city life. Stroll under the trees in dappled sunlight, pay your respects to the dead, gather your thoughts on a bench or just marvel at the beauty of the derelict chapel at the heart of the cemetery.
text.text: Perhaps the least well known of London’s ‘Magnificent Seven’ Victorian cemeteries (alongside the likes of Highgate and Kensal Green), this grassy and tranquil burial site makes for an idyllic escape from city life. Stroll under the trees in dappled sunlight, pay your respects to the dead, gather your thoughts on a bench or just marvel at the beauty of the derelict chapel at the heart of the cemetery.
Best for… community lovin’ and live music

tip.text:
Those lamenting the death of community spirit should get themselves to The Ivy House sharpish. The place is absolutely rife with the sweet stuff, from live music events and knitting classes, to the fact that back in 2012 - when faced with imminent closure - it became the first building in the UK to be bought for the community under the provisions of the Localism Act. It's now owned by an impressive 350 community shareholders.

Even if that knowledge doesn't make you feel all warm and fuzzy inside, the wood panelling, proper old-school stage, wooden booths, fairy lights, books and board games should do something for ya. And then there's the feeling you get when you walk in: that you're truly welcome and the unmistakable sense that we're all in this thing together. It'll be enough to prompt you to break into song at any moment. There are charming pubs, really charming pubs and then there's The Ivy House.

text.html: Sometimes the powers that be try and rob us little people of a good thing, and sometimes us little people say “fuck you” powers that be. The council came a callin’ a few years back and tried to turn Nunhead’s legendary local pub into flats: Nunhead said no. A passionate campaign and 371 community investors later and what do we have here - London’s first ever community-owned pub, and boy does it feel like it. Now that’s a love story, kids.
text.text: Sometimes the powers that be try and rob us little people of a good thing, and sometimes us little people say “fuck you” powers that be. The council came a callin’ a few years back and tried to turn Nunhead’s legendary local pub into flats: Nunhead said no. A passionate campaign and 371 community investors later and what do we have here - London’s first ever community-owned pub, and boy does it feel like it. Now that’s a love story, kids.
Brockley
Best for… your friendly neighbourhood restaurant

tip.text:
Emily and Ed opened The Orchard to give their new neighbours a relaxed and welcoming space to enjoy quality food and drink (the bookshelf and fish tank definitely instil an air of calm). A lot of thought has gone into the ethics of the business, meaning you'll only find London-brewed craft here, while produce is sourced from all local and independent farmers.

The food menu offers treats like crispy calamari with teriyaki and plum sauce, or a full, USA style stack of pancakes with bacon and maple syrup. Heck, people have been heard complimenting the sirloin steak from here as far away as Utah (yes, in America!). For your life-endangering thirst: Beavertown, Kernel and Brockley brewery to name a few, plus cocktailz.

text.text: The Orchard is all about being that go-to neighbourhood spot: a pub to some, a restaurant to others, a favourite to many. These guys are well into supporting independent producers where possible, so expect a hefty list of craft beers, brewed all over London, and dishes prepped with sustainably-sourced ingredients. Not afraid of getting their own hands dirty, they even make their own syrups and blackberry vodka (among other things)!
Best for… not taking yourself too seriously

tip.text:
You'll be hard pressed to find a more quirky or charming coffee spot in these ends, and The Broca sits in the starkest of contrast to its neighbour Browns of Brockley. This is the spot if you're after a refreshing, fun and zany hangout, full of random second-hand furniture and obscure props, posters and pastries galore.

This is a real community cafe: a point is made of employing Brockley and Deptford locals only, the baking is done onsite and since the move to gluten-free cakes, a grand total of zero people have noticed a difference (seems a shame to spill the secret). Most of the food here is vegan, but they might throw an egg on your brunch if you ask nicely. Full of character, cheer and life, The Broca is a proper wholesome part of this community.

text.html: Well this place is fun. Modelled on classic Canadian coffee shops, the idea was to create a chilled out space for kicking back in like it’s your own living room - if your living room features random furniture, colourful walls and trippy, psychedelic posters then you’re in luck. The food, drink and recruitment ethos? Localism - only Brockley & Deptford natives are employed, while suppliers are just as local.
text.text: Well this place is fun. Modelled on classic Canadian coffee shops, the idea was to create a chilled out space for kicking back in like it’s your own living room - if your living room features random furniture, colourful walls and trippy, psychedelic posters then you’re in luck. The food, drink and recruitment ethos? Localism - only Brockley & Deptford natives are employed, while suppliers are just as local.
Best for… specialist cawfee

tip.text:
Great for a solo coffee or a lunch date, this laid-back, modern café serves delicious coffee with a very big smile. The staff are super friendly and v knowledgeable of their beans, so don't be scared of asking questions if you're no coffee nerd. In fact these guys are so cool they've got merch in the form of caps and tees with their logo and cutesy catch phrases like 'making it frothy'. Whether you're on board with that or not you can't argue with a cheeky window seat to watch the world go by, paired with one of their delish' baked treats; or an artisan salt beef and gherkin sandwich.

Beware if you're heading in after the lunch rush that more of the fresh goods (bagels, salads and pastries) will have run out. So get a wiggle on!

text.html: If The Broca is that hyper, zany kid in your class rocking all sorts of colourful, mismatched hand-me-downs, then Browns of Brockley is that kid’s opposite. Y’know, the quietly serious and stylish minimalist, well into that obscure Japanese brand you’ve never heard of. Specialist coffee: you might not be cultured enough to taste a difference, but these guys can: they’re artisan and super nerdy when it comes to this stuff - and, more importantly, proud.
text.text: If The Broca is that hyper, zany kid in your class rocking all sorts of colourful, mismatched hand-me-downs, then Browns of Brockley is that kid’s opposite. Y’know, the quietly serious and stylish minimalist, well into that obscure Japanese brand you’ve never heard of. Specialist coffee: you might not be cultured enough to taste a difference, but these guys can: they’re artisan and super nerdy when it comes to this stuff - and, more importantly, proud.
Best for... homely cooking

tip.text:
There's no cooking like home cooking, and this mother-daughter enterprise, Masala Wala, is a real testament to that. Just ask the lucky people of Brockley who are treated to their authentic, flavoursome and seasonal Pakastani fare.

Offerings are simple: 4 dishes (2 meat, 2 vegan) prepared the traditional way, with halal meat and free-range chicken. If you're curious about homely Pakistani recipes passed down through the generations then this is the place to check out. Oh, it's BYOB too, and who doesn't love that?

text.text: There's no cooking like home cooking. Find us someone on this planet who doesn't agree. A mother-daughter enterprise, Masala Wala are filling South Londoners' tums with authentic, flavoursome and seasonal Pakistani dishes - none of that bland, creamy British curry nonsense. Offerings are simple: 4 dishes (2 meat, 2 vegan) prepared the traditional way, with halal meat and free-range chicken. If you're curious about homely Pakistani recipes passed down through the generations then this is the place to check out. Oh, it's BYOB too, and who doesn't love that?
Best for… backyard bites & bespoke boozin’

tip.text:
This family-run restaurant is full of surprises: on first entering you'd be forgiven for thinking you'd stepped into a cosy, almost poky bistro. A little explore will reveal multiple dining rooms, a conservatory and a far from poky garden - this outdoor space is arguably one of Brockley's true gems.

Food offerings are varied in style, although the overarching theme is Italian with a twist - you'll find anything from prawn and avocado spring rolls to clams fettuccine here, with a nordic seafood platter chucked in for good measure. Thirsty? Check the staff cocktails list behind the bar; each employee has designed a bespoke, lethal and tasty potion to test your liver.

text.text: When out and about in a given neighbourhood it’s worth knowing where the best garden is at - The Gantry have this award absolutely locked down in Brockley. There’s no way you’re expecting what’s out back when you first step onto the premises, and that’s a beautiful thing in itself: surprise! The lovely conservatory backs onto a real treat of a garden, so grab one of the bespoke staff cocktails, order you some clams and enjoy that fresh air.
Best for… a quick trip to the Caribbean

tip.text:
Unless you're in the local know (or have a habit of sticking your head in somewhat uninviting doors) you almost certainly aren't aware of this gem. The people of Brockley know and they love it: the charming women in Nu Spice have been serving up Caribbean food to SE natives for the last 18 years.

What do you go for? The jerk chicken with rice and peas is a fan favourite while we hear the likes of curry goat and steamed fish are stellar options also. Patties, plantain and punch (rum) complete your Caribbean experience.

text.text: If the bright yellow exterior doesn’t brighten your day up a bit then the smile you’re greeted with on entry will: welcome to one of Brockley’s longest standing institutions, filling tums with flavourful Caribbean food since ‘98. It might not look like much, but you don’t last 18 years serving up great value meals unless you’re doing something right, and more than one Brockley-ite confirmed that this is quite the legendary local eatery.
Best for… bargain beerz

tip.text:
That beer garden tho - Brockley locals are all about the Talbot, and with the outdoor setup they've got going on out front it's hard to blame 'em. Benches galore; perfect for kicking back with a pint after work and pretending it's actually hot.

While Brockley Ale is a mainstay on the taps here for obvious reasons, the rest of the pipes see five casks on rotation, a change occurring at the end of every keg. We wet our beaks on a strongly-flavoured cucumber beer when we were down. The Talbot's food offerings change monthly, always seasonal, and aim to have you dining in the finest sense of the word.

Get down on Thursdays for £2.50 pints!

text.text: Beer and the great outdoors are a certified match made in heaven, hence the invention of beer gardens (duh). So, we rightly get excited when we come across a generous space for a spot of al fresco boozing - Brockley can boast The Talbot, a great pub with benches galore out front, packed with locals loosening their ties after clocking out at work. Better yet, £2.50 pints are on the agenda every Thursday, so we’ll be seeing you there.
